Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit
Most concepts to build giant telescopes are based on extending the design of existing telescopes to larger sizes. For example, the Thirty Meter Telescope (TMT) and Giant Magellan Telescope (GMT) are based on the Keck design and on spin casting furnace technology. While both approaches are based on the proven technology of the 1980?s, these designs come with a high price tag because substantial engineering investments are required when scaling to a 30-m aperture; the primary mirror itself is expected to have a surface figure good to tens of nanometer in the presence of wind and gravitational deflections and the atmospheric turbulence must then be corrected by an adaptive optics (AO) system placed between the primary mirror and detector operating with many thousand actuators. An alternative approach is to use smaller segments, of the order of a few thousands, that are controlled at higher bandwidths to remove the effects of atmospheric turbulence and windshake at the primary mirror. This will produce a high performance telescope at significantly lower cost. The proposed research plans to address the control of the reflective surface of the primary mirror, a major technological challenge of ATLAS design. This work plans to leverage on the investigators? preliminary work on the application of recently developed distributed control techniques, and on their experimental test rigs to fully validate their control approach.

Broader Impact
This work will have implications to future astronomical and scientific discovery technologies. It will enable the building the construction of large telescopes by astronomers. In addition, the main educational impact of this effort will be in terms of (i) Developing courses and educational materials that discuss systematic approaches for control of large telescopic systems. (ii) Maintaining a Web-page at the University of Illinois which will be used to disseminate new results within the members of the ATLAS team as well as to the broader scientific and research community, including Argonne National Laboratories.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Most concepts to build giant telescopes are based on extending the design of existing telescopes to larger sizes. For example, the Thirty Meter Telescope (TMT) and Giant Magellan Telescope (GMT) are based on the Keck design and on spin casting furnace technology. While both approaches are based on the proven technology of the 1980’s, these designs come with a high price tag because substantial engineering investments are required when scaling to a 30-m aperture; the primary mirror itself is expected to have a surface figure good to tens of nanometer in the presence of wind and gravitational deflections and the atmospheric turbulence must then be corrected by an adaptive optics (AO) system placed between the primary mirror and detector operating with many thousand actuators. An alternative approach is to use smaller segments, of the order of a few thousands, that are controlled at higher bandwidths to remove the effects of atmospheric turbulence and windshake at the primary mirror. This will produce a high performance telescope at significantly lower cost and would revolutionize almost all other areas of astronomy.

The ATLAS telescope concept that the investigators conducted research on, captures precisely this approach. The research addressed several topics relevant to  the control of the reflective surface of the primary mirror.  In particular,  distributed control and identification techniques were studied, including the analysis and optimal synthesis problem under noisy, delayed, failed and restricted communication between spatiotemporal control substations.  Several of our results in this effort have appeared in leading journals and conference proceedings in control and estimation.

 A distributed  ID algorithm was developed to ensure spatial and temporal closeness of the parameter estimates which in turn ensures stability of the adaptive, distributed and separation based control scheme. This is important as the spatiotemporal model of the telescope dynamics contains uncertain parameters such as damping and natural frequencies that need to be identified for accurate control.   The techniques developed are relevant not only to the ATLAS concept but also to a number of current and future complex system applications such as platoon formations of vehicles, congestion control of networks, micro-electro-mechanical systems, power systems, production lines and chemical processes, etc.  The project also led to the development of detection methods for malicious attacks for general systems which  has ramifications to telescopes as they have several digital components that can be manipulated by an attacker to the facility. 

In summary, the project has contributed to future astronomical and scientific discovery technologies for  building large telescopes by astronomers.  In fact, the ATLAS concept of an adaptive primary mirror, defines a new generation of not-so-expensive telescopes, telescopes that will span a wide range of aperture, a wide range of science applications, and especially a wide range of sites including the Antarctic and the Moon. The components in the ATLAS primary mirror design are modular, not massive and, on the premise of the proposed work, it is anticipated that they will be dominant in the 21st century.
